senses.de: Something heavy that you have to carry.
senses.ex: The fireman lifted the burden of the old woman out of the burning house.

Tips.title: Physical Load
Tips.description: Refers to actual objects that are difficult to carry due to weight or size.
Tips.example: Hikers often share the burden of the group's supplies.

Tips.title: Not Always Literal
Tips.description: Can describe emotional stress similar to carrying something heavy.
Tips.example: After the loss, the grief became a heavy burden for her.

senses.de: A duty, responsibility, or obligation that causes worry or difficulty.
senses.ex: The burden of proof rests on the prosecution in a criminal trial.

Tips.title: Emotional Weight
Tips.description: Emphasizes that responsibilities can be emotionally draining, not just challenging.
Tips.example: Being the sole provider for his family was a huge burden to him.

Tips.title: Legal Specificity
Tips.description: In legal contexts, indicates specific responsibilities like 'burden of proof'.
Tips.example: The defense lawyer explained the burden of proof to the jury.

Tips.title: Shared vs. Solo
Tips.description: Can imply whether a responsibility is carried alone or with others.
Tips.example: The community joined forces to ease the burden of rebuilding.

senses.de: To put a heavy load or responsibility on someone or something.
senses.ex: She didn't want to burden him with her problems.

Tips.title: Imposition Sense
Tips.description: When used as a verb, it often suggests an unwelcome or unexpected imposition.
Tips.example: He didn't want to burden his friend with his financial troubles.

Tips.title: Figurative Application
Tips.description: Can refer to adding responsibilities that are not tangible or visible.
Tips.example: The new regulations burdened the small business with extra paperwork.

senses.de: The main idea or theme in a speech, book, or other work.
senses.ex: The burden of his speech was the importance of education.

Tips.title: Core Message
Tips.description: In creative works, 'burden' refers to a central message or takeaway.
Tips.example: The burden of the novel is the protagonist's struggle with identity.

Tips.title: Interpretation Clue
Tips.description: Indicates that understanding the 'burden' helps comprehend a work's full meaning.
Tips.example: The teacher asked what the burden of the poem was to assess interpretation skills.

Duty.wordDefinition:
Burden refers to something that is heavy, oppressive or difficult to manage, whereas duty refers to a task or responsibility that needs to be fulfilled.

Duty is something that you are responsible for, that you must fulfill or accomplish.

Duties can be assigned or chosen, and they are often linked to personal, professional, or social expectations.

For example, a duty could be to attend school regularly, to do your homework, or to help your grandmother with grocery shopping.

A burden is something difficult and unwanted that is imposed on you, while a duty is a task or responsibility that you are expected to accomplish as a matter of obligation or commitment.

Encumbrance.wordDefinition:
Both burden and encumbrance refer to something that causes difficulty or inconvenience, but there is a slight difference in their usage.

Encumbrance on the other hand, refers more specifically to something that is a hindrance or obstacle, such as a legal or financial burden that limits one's freedom or progress.

For example, a property with an encumbrance, such as a lien or mortgage, may be more difficult to sell.

In simpler terms, a burden is something that weighs you down, while an encumbrance is something that blocks your way.

Load.wordDefinition:
Both burden and load refer to something that is heavy or difficult to carry or manage.

However, burden often implies a more emotional or psychological weight, while load is generally used to describe a physical weight.

You might say that a truck is carrying a heavy load of bricks.

Burden is more commonly used in figurative or emotional contexts, while load is used more often for physical, concrete objects.

Obligation.wordDefinition:
Burden refers to something that is heavy or difficult to bear, while obligation refers to something that must be done because of a sense of duty or responsibility.

On the other hand, paying back a loan could be considered an obligation because it is required by a sense of responsibility to fulfill a financial commitment.

While both words can be used in various contexts, burden is generally used to describe something that causes difficulty, while obligation describes something that is required or expected.

Onus.wordDefinition:
Both burden and onus refer to something that is difficult to bear or an obligation that is imposed upon someone.

However, burden involves a feeling of weight or heaviness, while onus involves a legal or moral responsibility.

A legal responsibility or duty imposed on an individual falls under the category of onus.

Burden pertains to a heavy load or a difficult task, and onus pertains to a legal or moral obligation.

Pressure.wordDefinition:
Pressure is a force that is exerted upon a person to do or achieve something.

For example, the pressure to do well on an exam can come from a student's desire to get good grades or from their parents' expectations.

A burden is a difficult responsibility that a person has to deal with, while pressure is a force that pushes a person to perform or achieve something.

Responsibility.wordDefinition:
Responsibility refers to a duty or obligation that one has to fulfill, such as taking care of someone or completing a task.

Burden refers to something negative that is difficult to handle while responsibility refers to something positive that one should take care of.

The term burden can be used when someone feels weighed down by something unpleasant, while responsibility can be applied when someone is expected to do something important or necessary.

Weight.wordDefinition:
Both burden and weight refer to something that is heavy, but they are used in different contexts.

Weight usually refers to the physical heaviness of an object or a person's body. For example, a box may be heavy in weight, or a person may be concerned about their weight if they are trying to lose or gain weight.

Burden refers to heavy responsibilities, while weight refers to the physical heaviness of an object or person's body.
